alert.note: Alert for Val Verde (Texas) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued August 23 at 10:28AM CDT until August 23 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS Austin-San Antonio
info.description: ...Observed flooding changed from Moderate to Major severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Texas... Rio Grande At Foster Ranch affecting Val Verde County. For the Rio Grande...including Foster Ranch, Pandale Crossing, Langtry, Cauthorn Ranch Near Juno, Bakers Crossing 19N Of Comstock, and Pafford Crossing nr Comstock. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Major flooding is occurring. * WHERE...Rio Grande at Foster Ranch. * WHEN...Until late this evening. * IMPACTS...At 22.0 feet, (6.7 meters), major lowland flooding occurs above Dryden to Amistad Reservoir. Below Foster Ranch, the river is one third mile wide and covers the right flood plain to the canyon wall. Campers, autos, gear and livestock flood anywhere in the Rio Grande canyon bottom and will wash downstream. Canoeing and kayaking are extremely dangerous in the Rio Grande River above Dryden to Amistad Reservoir. Turbulent flow, huge eddies and whirlpools occur. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:15 AM CDT Wednesday the stage was 22.5 feet. - Bankfull stage is 14.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:15 AM CDT Wednesday was 22.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late tonight and continue falling to 1.9 feet Monday morning. - Flood stage is 14.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 22.7 feet on 07/18/1976. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (1 pm CDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Thu Fri Sat Rio Grande Foster Ranc 14.0 22.5 Wed 10 am CD 5.4 2.4 2.1 &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. To escape rising water, take the shortest path to higher ground. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued this evening at 900 PM CDT.
